title: California bans 'lunch shaming' and guarantees all students get fed with new law
text:
California's governor has signed into law a bill that guarantees all students a state-funded meal of their choice, even if their parent or guardian has unpaid meal fees.

The measure bans the practice of 'lunch shaming,' in which students who owe the school money for meals are denied food or given a cheaper alternative meal.

Under the new law, a school can no longer give a student a cheaper alternative meal.

California Governor Gavin Newsom signed a law that bans the practice of 'lunch shaming,' in which students who owe the school money for meals are denied food or given a cheaper alternative meal

In a statement Saturday, Gov. Gavin Newsom thanked Ryan Kyote, a third-grader at an elementary school in Napa County who brought national attention to the practice

In a statement Saturday, Gov. Gavin Newsom thanked Ryan Kyote, a third-grader at an elementary school in Napa County who brought national attention to the practice earlier this year by paying for all the food service bills of his fellow students at the school.

'I want to thank Ryan for his empathy and his courage in bringing awareness to this important issue,' Newsom said.

Newsom and Kyote met earlier in the year to discuss ways to tackle the issue.

'I want to thank Ryan for his empathy and his courage in bringing awareness to this important issue,' Newsom said.

The law - SB 265 - was created by Senator Robert Hertzberg (D- Van Nuys) and ensures that all 'students receive a state reimbursable meal of their choice, even if their parent or guardian has unpaid meal fees.'

The law - SB 265 - was created by Senator Robert Hertzberg (D- Van Nuys)

'Specifically, SB 265 amends the Child Hunger Prevention and Fair Treatment Act of 2017 to require all local educational agencies, including school districts, county offices of education, and charter schools that provide free and reduced meals, to invalidate policies that call for a student whose parent or guardian has unpaid meal fees be given an alternative meal,' a release from the governor's office said on Saturday.

The release from the Newsom's office said that with the 2019 Budget Act, the governor made the 'highest-ever investment in K-14 education' including a 19.3 per cent increase for funding in special education.

'Creating a "California for All" means ensuring schools are inclusive, accepting, and welcoming of all kids. These bills help move us closer to that goal,' added. Governor Newsom.

In May, the Governor and First Partner Jennifer Siebel Newsom launched the 'Parents Agenda' which works to help alleviate some costs of living for California parents.
description: California Governor Gavin Newsom signed a law that bans the practice of 'lunch shaming,' and shared that third-grade activist Ryan Kyote (left) helped motivate him to work towards the change.
